title: Arrays (Fixed-Size Collections)

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Array declaration. int[] numbers or string[] names. Square brackets [] make it array. Type specifies what it holds.
Creates array with specified size. new int[5] makes array holding 5 integers. Size can't change after creation!
Access element at position. Indexing starts at 0! First element: arr[0]. Last element: arr[arr.Length - 1]. arr[5] for 5-item array is ERROR!
Property (not method - no parentheses!). Returns number of elements. arr.Length for 5 elements = 5. Use in loops: i < arr.Length.

challenge.instructions:
Create a student grade manager!

1. Ask how many students (create array of that size)
2. Use loop to get each student's name (string array)
3. Use loop to get each student's score (int array)
4. Calculate and display:
   - Each student with their score
   - Class average
   - Highest score and student name
   - Lowest score and student name
   - How many students passed (score >= 60)
5. Sort and display all students by score (descending)

Example:
How many students? 3

Student 1 name: Alice
Student 1 score: 85
Student 2 name: Bob
Student 2 score: 92
Student 3 name: Charlie
Student 3 score: 78

=== RESULTS ===
Alice: 85
Bob: 92
Charlie: 78
Class average: 85.0
Highest: Bob (92)
Lowest: Charlie (78)
Passed: 3/3
challenge.hint: Create arrays with new string[count] and new int[count]. Loop with i < count to fill. Sum all scores then divide by count for average. Track max/min with if (score > highest). Count passes with if (score >= 60) passedCount++.
commonStickingPoints: Index out of bounds: arr[5] on 5-element array is ERROR! Valid indices: 0-4. Last index is arr.Length - 1 NOT arr.Length! Very common beginner mistake.
Fixed size: Can't do arr.Add() or grow array! Size set at creation. int[] arr = new int[5]; stays 5 forever. Use List<T> for dynamic size (next lesson).
Forgetting new: int[] arr; arr[0] = 5; ERROR! Must initialize: int[] arr = new int[5]; or int[] arr = {1,2,3}; Empty declaration not enough!
Type mixing: int[] numbers = {1, 2, \"three\"}; ERROR! Array holds ONE type only. All int OR all string, never mixed. Use object[] for mixed (advanced).
